comments:
Writing code with platform independency in mind, setAlpha doesn't seem to 
cause any problems on Windows, but crashes horribly when running it on Linux.  
Either the required libraries should be included in the build, or the method 
should fail gracefully.

org.eclipse.swt.SWTException: Unable to load graphics library [Cairo is 
required] (java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError)
	at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:2942)
	at org.eclipse.swt.graphics.Device.checkCairo(Device.java:154)
	at org.eclipse.swt.graphics.GC.initCairo(GC.java:2268)
	at org.eclipse.swt.graphics.GC.setAlpha(GC.java:2444)
	at org.eclipse.draw2d.SWTGraphics.setAlpha(SWTGraphics.java:912)

It doesn't crash horribly, it throws an exception so the application can decide
what to do if cairo is not available.  This is the same as on Windows if GDI+ is
not available (Windows 2000 and earlier).

SWT 3.1 depends on cairo 0.4.0 which is a development snapshot.  A pre-built
binary of cairo 0.4.0 is included with Eclipse in the root directory beside the
eclipse executable, and also in the SWT standalone download for 3.1. 
Applications requiring the advanced graphics API under Linux should put the
appropriate path including this library on the LD_LIBRARY_PATH.
